channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Can’t find the right job? Build your own! Remote Perl role in Australia
item.description: If you’re a senior Perl developer — you’ve already got the most important component of what our client is looking for. Other important bits: in an ideal world, you’ll have experience with most or all of Catalyst, REST, Dancer2, Moo, DBlx::Class, MySQL, Postgres, and docker. Want to add extra flair? AngularJS or Vue would take you to the next level.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they’re subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Located in glorious Malta, they offer a supportive team that believes in open communication and solving problems together.

item.title: A Gem of a Perl role. Remote within UK
item.description: You’ll need experience writing great Perl, along with valid HTML, Javascript, and CSS. Toss in experience with SQL and ORMs like DBIx::Class and add your excellent Linux experience (Debian lovers come this way) and you’ve got the skill set this role requires. Your day-to-day routine will include managing the full life-cycle of software projects of all sizes.

item.title: Let’s get SaaSsy! Remote Perl role within US time zone
item.description: Our client is the world’s leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients ranging from first responders and engineers to manufacturers and educators. The successful candidate is a Perl developer with Catalyst and Dblx::Class. You’ve been around the block and you know your stuff.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: Dancer2: Install Perl on Linux and Mac OSX
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: 2 Fractions and a Prime
item.description: Simon use of Number::Fraction to deal with the task 'Curious Fraction Tree' is really interesting. Thank you for sharing new ideas.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 146: Curious Prime
item.description: Reference point in the blog to the task is the main attraction for me. Roger has been providing solutions in many other languages too.

item.title: Large primes and curious fractions
item.description: Peter discussion of the '10001st Prime Number' task is not be missed imho. Thank you Peter for your contributions..

item.title: Curious Fraction Tree
item.description: Well crafted presentation with two different approaches. Mark always make the task look simple. Well done.

item.title: 10001st Prime Number
item.description: Compact one liner in Raku is the solution by Mark. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 146
item.description: Very impressive one-liner solution in Perl by Luis. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 146: the first challenge of the year!
item.description: Luca is one of Raku fan in the team. This week he shared Raku class solution. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 146: Prime Numbers and Fraction Tree
item.description: Laurent is on mission of exploring guest languages these days. Thank you for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #146
item.description: James is known for compact and elgant solutions. I simply love his solutions. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 146
item.description: Cool one liner in Raku for the 10001st prime number. Always a pleasure to read his blog.

item.title: PWC146 - Curious Fraction Tree
item.description: Flavio is very clever, sharing the finer details. The best solution imho so far. Thank you.

item.title: PWC146 - 10001st Prime Number
item.description: Flavio continued showing his power of Raku skills with compact solution. Great work, keep it up.

item.title: Fractions, Trees and Primes: Weekly Challenge 146
item.description: Elegant use of OOP method to solve the Curious Fraction Tree task. You don't want to miss it.

item.title: Fractionally Prime with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne always gives more than just the task. This week also we have dot file generation. Thank you for sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Sieve of Atkin / Curious Fraction Tree
item.description: Thank you Adam for sharing 'Sieve of Atkin' method of determining prime number. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 146: Curious Fraction Tree
item.description: Abigail presented the task in a simple and easy to read format. Thanks for your help.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 146: 10001st Prime Number
item.description: Another cool use of another CPAN module as shown by Abigail.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 142
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 145
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "10001st Prime Number" and "Curious Fraction Tree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 147
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Truncatable Prime" and "Pentagon Numbers". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Programming in 1987 Versus Today
item.description: Curtis sharing his programming days in 1987. A very entertaining blog.

item.title: GNU Parallel's 20th birthday
item.description: On 2022-01-06 GNU Parallel completed 20 years old. Please check out how Perl is related to it.

item.title: Opening Files Quickly from Inside vim
item.description: It is not something new to many but in this blog he is talking how to use 'ot' within vim.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: closure
item.description: This weekly blog by Tom shares the insights of 'closure' in a compact and cocise way.

item.title: Perl warnings and the warn function
item.description: A very interesting discussion of 'warn' and 'warnings'. Highly recommended.

item.title: Are Microservices the Next Phase of Object-Oriented Programming?
item.description: Curtis sharing the little secrets about OOP and it's follow up with Microservice. The discussion about Inheritance is fascinating. Thank you great blog. Please keep it coming regularly.

item.title: #546 - Perl Books
item.description:
Hi there

Welcome to my first edition of the year 2022 and 95th edition overall.

I remember, there was a time when O'Reilly group published many Perl books. Then came few other publishing house, like Manning publication. I am sure you must have owned handfull of Perl books from these publishers. Recent times, not many Perl books written, except one or two by brian d foy. A friend of mine, donated all his Perl books to a local library as he is moving to Python. It is sad state to be honest. Recently, I came across a Facebook post by a friend of mine about a perl book Extending and Embedding Perl. I knew about it but never had the chance to read it. So I decided to buy a used copy from Amazon. I must confess, I was missing a big deal. If you haven't read it then you must check out. I am sure, you can find online FREE copy. By the way, I have kept all my Perl books safe. I like to read physical book and not online version.

With new years, there is a trend of new year resolution. As far as I am concerned, I stopped making any resolution two years ago. But this year, I decided to make one and stick to it. And the resolution is to get the draft of my first Perl book out as soon as possible. It has been going on for months now. It is embarassing now to even talk about it. There are so many things going on at the same time, I hardly find time for the book. Please wish me luck.

Long time ago, Gabor, started a compaign to do live video on Perl. He even did few pair-programming sessions and it was very popular. But then there has been no noise on that front in recent time. I used to do YouTube for the weekly challenge during the middle of last year and then I also stopped it because of lack of time. Last month, I started doing video again for the weekly challenge. It gives me immense pleasure when I see comments on my video. Someone recently commented on one my video and requested I should do videos of past challenges as well. I have to manage my time carefully otherwise my first book would be neglected again. Having said, I am not giving up on making video for weekly challenge. If you are interested then please do check out my YouTube Channel.

There is one good news shared by Curtis that the MMVP (minimally minimal viable product) RFC for Corinna has been sent to P5P. I am keeping my fingers crossed.

Last but not the least, you please look after yourself and loved ones.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
